title: French Open 2025 Day Two Recap
description: The Day Two recap of the 2025 French Open saw the Round of 128 unfold with a blend of dominant displays, surprising upsets, and intense battles on Roland Garrosâ€™s red clay. Defending champion Carlos Alcaraz led the charge with a polished performance to launch his title defence, while Daniel Altmaier delivered the tournamentâ€™s first major â€¦
author: Jonathan
excerpt: The Day Two recap of the 2025 French Open saw the Round of 128 unfold with a blend of dominant displays, surprising upsets, and intense battles on Roland Garros's red clay. Defending champion Carlos A
text: The Day Two recap of the 2025 French Open saw the Round of 128 unfold with a blend of dominant displays, surprising upsets, and intense battles on Roland Garrosâ€™s red clay. Defending champion Carlos Alcaraz led the charge with a polished performance to launch his title defence, while Daniel Altmaier delivered the tournamentâ€™s first major shock by toppling fourth seed Taylor Fritz. Gabriel Diallo turned heads with a statement win over 18th seed Francisco Cerundolo, and World No. 1 Jannik Sinner showed his resilience in a third-set comeback against Arthur Rinderknech under the Court Philippe-Chatrier lights. The full results, recap, and highlights from day two are below. Day Two French Open 2025 Round of 128 Results Winner Loser Scoreline Jannik Sinner (1) Arthur Rinderknech 6-4 6-3 7-5 Richard Gasquet Terence Atmane 6-2 2-6 6-3 6-0 Jiri Lehecka Jordan Thompson 6-4 6-2 6-1 Alejandro Davidovich Fokina (26) Pablo Llamas Ruiz 6-3 6-2 6-7(4) 6-3 Jaume Munar Camilo Ugo Carabelli 6-4 6-1 7-5 Arthur Fils (14) Nicolas Jarry 6-3 6-4 6-7(6) 603 Gabriel Diallo Francisco Cerundolo (18) 7-5 6-3 6-4 Tallon Griekspoor Marcos Giron 4-6 6-3 6-4 7-5 Jacob Fearnley Stan Wawrinka 7-6(7) 6-3 6-2 Ugo Humbert (22) Christopher Oâ€™Connell 7-5 6-3 7-6(3) Denis Shapovalov (27) Portero MartÃ­nez 6-2 6-0 6-3 Filip Misolic Yibing Bu 5-7 7-6(3) 7-6(4) 6-1 Miomir Kecmanovic SebastiÃ¡n BÃ¡ez 6-7(3) 6-7(4) 6-4 6-2 6-2 Sebastian Korda (23) Luciano Darderi 6-2 4-6 6-3 6-2 Daniel Altmaier Taylor Fritz (4) 7-5 3-6 6-3 6-1 Casper Ruud (7) Albert Ramos ViÃ±olas 6-3 -4 6-2 Alejandro Tabilo Arthur Cazaux 5-7 6-3 6-2 1-6 6-3 Alexei Popyrin (25) Yoshihito Nishioka 7-5 6-4 1-2 (RET) Holger Rune (10) Roberto Bautista Agut 6-7(4) 6-4 6-3 6-2 Hugo Gaston Ugo Blanchet 2-6 6-0 2-6 6-3 6-4 Stefanos Tsitsipas (20) TomÃ¡s MartÃ­n Etcheverry 7-5 6-3 6-4 Karen Khachanov Aleksandar Vukic 6-4 6-4 6-4 Sebastian Ofner Jan-Lennard Struff 7-6(5) 6-3 6-7(5) 6-2 Carlos Alcaraz (2) Giulio Zeppieri 6-3 6-4 6-2 Daily Recap Carlos Alcaraz (2) def. Giulio Zeppieri 6-3, 6-4, 6-2 Carlos Alcaraz was all business in his first-round demolition of qualifier Giulio Zeppieri as he made a successful start to his title defence. The Spaniard cruised through 6-3, 6-4, 6-2 in one hour and 56 minutes, saving all three break points he faced, and Zeppieri had no real answers to the tennis Alcaraz served up. Fresh off ATP Masters 1000 titles in Monte-Carlo and Rome, Alcaraz reclaimed the World No. 2 spot in the ATP Rankings last week and he faces Fabian Marozsan in round two, who upset him a couple of years back in Rome. It was really, really solid. The first round of the tournament is never easy, coming here as the defending champion could be even tougher. But I just started pretty well, and kept my good pace during the whole match. I tried to be focused on my game, to get a good rhythm. Iâ€™m just really proud of my start here at Roland Garros, where I was really excited to play my first match this year. Alcaraz on his win. Daniel Altmaier def. Taylor Fritz (4) 7-5, 3-6, 6-3, 6-1 Altmaier delivered the tournamentâ€™s first major upset, outgunning fourth seed Fritz in a two-hour, 41-minute battle. The No. 66-ranked German blasted 44 winners to notch his fifth career Top-10 win and third at Roland Garros. The American, who lost his first Roland Garros opening-round match since 2018, has been struggling with an injury during the clay swing and is way off the pace on the red dirt. Once you get him into the forecourt, heâ€™s relatively clueless about what to do, and when you hear certain players on tour say todayâ€™s Top 10 is much stronger now than it was 10 years ago, you just have to laugh ðŸ¤£ Gabriel Diallo def. Francisco Cerundolo (18) 7-5, 6-3, 6-4 Canadaâ€™s Diallo stunned 18th seed Cerundolo in a two-hour, 10-minute upset on Court 13, marking his first Roland Garros main-draw win. I had Cerundolo making the quarter finals ðŸ™ˆ but the No. 54-ranked Canadian broke late in the first set, rallied from an early deficit in the second, and sealed the third with a key break, firing 27 winners and four aces. Cerundolo has been a clay-court standout with a 19-9 record in 2025, but he didnâ€™t get a read on Dialloâ€™s serve and had one of those bad days at the office. Holger Rune (10) def. Roberto Bautista Agut 6-7(4), 6-4, 6-3, 6-2 Rune battled past Bautista Agut to secure his second-round spot, setting up a date with Emilio Nava. The Dane is on a potential fourth-round collision course with Lorenzo Musetti. With Fritz out, Rune and Musetti are the top seeds in their quarter, eyeing deep runs after Runeâ€™s back-to-back quarter-finals (2022-23) and Musettiâ€™s fourth-round showings (2021, 2023). Jannik Sinner (1) def. Arthur Rinderknech 6-4, 6-3, 7-5 World No. 1 Jannik Sinner battled through a tricky night session on Court Philippe-Chatrier, overcoming a spirited Arthur Rinderknech and a raucous French crowd to win 6-4, 6-3, 7-5 in two hours and five minutes. Sinner started strong, taking the first set 6-4 with 83% first-serve points won and saving all break points. That typical Sinner precision was evident, with eight winners and just three unforced errors in the opener. The second set saw Sinner maintain control, breaking Rinderknechâ€™s serve twice to secure a 6-3 lead, despite the Frenchmanâ€™s aggressive serve-and-volley tactics and some powerful serving. The third set turned dramatic as Rinderknech, fueled by the home crowdâ€™s Mexican wave and cheers, surged to a 5-2 lead with two breaks of Sinnerâ€™s serve. However, the Italian showed ice-cool composure, reeling off five straight games, capitalising on Rinderknechâ€™s 47 unforced errors and a critical double fault to seal the match. Other Notable Results Richard Gasquet def. Terence Atmane 6-2, 2-6, 6-3, 6-0: The Frenchman capitalised on Atmaneâ€™s cramps in the third set to roll through, and he faces Jannik Sinner next, potentially his last match at Roland Garros. Alejandro Davidovich Fokina (26) def. Pablo Llamas Ruiz 6-3, 6-2, 6-7(4), 6-3: The Spaniard survived a third-set scare, but last season, this match would probably have gone deep into the fifth set, so kudos to Fokina. Jacob Fearnley def. Stan Wawrinka 7-6(7), 6-3, 6-2: The Brit upset the veteran who I thought might have offered a bit more given he played nicely in some Challengers pre French Open. Denis Shapovalov (27) def. Portero MartÃ­nez 6-2, 6-0, 6-3: Shapovalov was ruthless in a result I didnâ€™t expect, as he has been struggling for form. Miomir Kecmanovic def. SebastiÃ¡n BÃ¡ez 6-7(3), 6-7(4), 6-4, 6-2, 6-2: A gritty five-set comeback for the Serb. Stefanos Tsitsipas (20) def. TomÃ¡s MartÃ­n Etcheverry 7-5, 6-3, 6-4: Tsitsipas looked sharp on the clay and considering how heâ€™s been playing, seeing off Etcheverry in straights is a good showing. Sebastian Ofner def. Jan-Lennard Struff 7-6(5), 6-3, 6-7(5), 6-2: Ofner held firm in a four-set battle, and the Austrian has played some solid stuff since he came back from his foot surgery. Hugo Gaston def. Ugo Blanchet 2-6, 6-0, 2-6, 6-3, 6-4: Gaston fought back in a rollercoaster five-setter with his creative shot-making, reminiscent of his 2020 fourth-round run, he sets up a second-round clash with the winner of Alex de Minaur vs. Zhizhen Zhang. Highlights French Open 2025 Day Three Round of 128 Matches Andrey Rublev (17) vs Lloyd Harris (Q) Maxime Marterer (Q) vs Adam Walton Nicolas Jarry vs Arthur Fils (14) Alex de Minaur (9) vs Laslo Djere Alexander Bublik vs James Duckworth Nikoloz Basalashvili (Q) vs Henrique Rocha (Q) Alexandre Muller vs Jakub Mensik (19) Hubert Hurkacz (30) vs Joao Fonseca Pierre-Hugues Herbert (WC) vs Benjamin Bonzi Gael Monfils vs Hugo Dellien Mattia Bellucci vs Jack Draper (5) Alexander Zverev (3) vs Learner Tien Jesper De Jong vs Francesco Passaro Marin Cilic (LL) vs Flavio Cobolli Matteo Arnaldi vs Felix Auger-Aliassime (29) Alexander Shevchenko (LL) vs Dusan Lajovic Ethan Quinn (Q) vs Grigor Dimitrov (16) Daniil Medvedev (11) vs Cameron Norrie Aleksandar Kovacevic vs Federico Agustin Gomez Christopher Oâ€™Connell vs Ugo Humbert (22) Corentin Moutet vs Clement Tabur (Q) Mackenzie McDonald vs Novak Djokovic (6)
html:
The Day Two recap of the 2025 French Open saw the Round of 128 unfold with a blend of dominant displays, surprising upsets, and intense battles on Roland Garrosâ€™s red clay.

Defending champion Carlos Alcaraz led the charge with a polished performance to launch his title defence, while Daniel Altmaier delivered the tournamentâ€™s first major shock by toppling fourth seed Taylor Fritz.

Gabriel Diallo turned heads with a statement win over 18th seed Francisco Cerundolo, and World No. 1 Jannik Sinner showed his resilience in a third-set comeback against Arthur Rinderknech under the Court Philippe-Chatrier lights.

The full results, recap, and highlights from day two are below.

Day Two French Open 2025 Round of 128 Results

Winner Loser Scoreline
Jannik Sinner (1) Arthur Rinderknech 6-4 6-3 7-5
Richard Gasquet Terence Atmane 6-2 2-6 6-3 6-0
Jiri Lehecka Jordan Thompson 6-4 6-2 6-1
Alejandro Davidovich Fokina (26) Pablo Llamas Ruiz 6-3 6-2 6-7(4) 6-3
Jaume Munar Camilo Ugo Carabelli 6-4 6-1 7-5
Arthur Fils (14) Nicolas Jarry 6-3 6-4 6-7(6) 603
Gabriel Diallo Francisco Cerundolo (18) 7-5 6-3 6-4
Tallon Griekspoor Marcos Giron 4-6 6-3 6-4 7-5
Jacob Fearnley Stan Wawrinka 7-6(7) 6-3 6-2
Ugo Humbert (22) Christopher Oâ€™Connell 7-5 6-3 7-6(3)
Denis Shapovalov (27) Portero MartÃ­nez 6-2 6-0 6-3
Filip Misolic Yibing Bu 5-7 7-6(3) 7-6(4) 6-1
Miomir Kecmanovic SebastiÃ¡n BÃ¡ez 6-7(3) 6-7(4) 6-4 6-2 6-2
Sebastian Korda (23) Luciano Darderi 6-2 4-6 6-3 6-2
Daniel Altmaier Taylor Fritz (4) 7-5 3-6 6-3 6-1
Casper Ruud (7) Albert Ramos ViÃ±olas 6-3 -4 6-2
Alejandro Tabilo Arthur Cazaux 5-7 6-3 6-2 1-6 6-3
Alexei Popyrin (25) Yoshihito Nishioka 7-5 6-4 1-2 (RET)
Holger Rune (10) Roberto Bautista Agut 6-7(4) 6-4 6-3 6-2
Hugo Gaston Ugo Blanchet 2-6 6-0 2-6 6-3 6-4
Stefanos Tsitsipas (20) TomÃ¡s MartÃ­n Etcheverry 7-5 6-3 6-4
Karen Khachanov Aleksandar Vukic 6-4 6-4 6-4
Sebastian Ofner Jan-Lennard Struff 7-6(5) 6-3 6-7(5) 6-2
Carlos Alcaraz (2) Giulio Zeppieri 6-3 6-4 6-2

Daily Recap

Carlos Alcaraz (2) def. Giulio Zeppieri 6-3, 6-4, 6-2

Carlos Alcaraz was all business in his first-round demolition of qualifier Giulio Zeppieri as he made a successful start to his title defence.

The Spaniard cruised through 6-3, 6-4, 6-2 in one hour and 56 minutes, saving all three break points he faced, and Zeppieri had no real answers to the tennis Alcaraz served up.

Fresh off ATP Masters 1000 titles in Monte-Carlo and Rome, Alcaraz reclaimed the World No. 2 spot in the ATP Rankings last week and he faces Fabian Marozsan in round two, who upset him a couple of years back in Rome.

It was really, really solid. The first round of the tournament is never easy, coming here as the defending champion could be even tougher. But I just started pretty well, and kept my good pace during the whole match. I tried to be focused on my game, to get a good rhythm. Iâ€™m just really proud of my start here at Roland Garros, where I was really excited to play my first match this year. Alcaraz on his win.

Daniel Altmaier def. Taylor Fritz (4) 7-5, 3-6, 6-3, 6-1

Altmaier delivered the tournamentâ€™s first major upset, outgunning fourth seed Fritz in a two-hour, 41-minute battle.

The No. 66-ranked German blasted 44 winners to notch his fifth career Top-10 win and third at Roland Garros.

The American, who lost his first Roland Garros opening-round match since 2018, has been struggling with an injury during the clay swing and is way off the pace on the red dirt.

Once you get him into the forecourt, heâ€™s relatively clueless about what to do, and when you hear certain players on tour say todayâ€™s Top 10 is much stronger now than it was 10 years ago, you just have to laugh ðŸ¤£

Gabriel Diallo def. Francisco Cerundolo (18) 7-5, 6-3, 6-4

Canadaâ€™s Diallo stunned 18th seed Cerundolo in a two-hour, 10-minute upset on Court 13, marking his first Roland Garros main-draw win.

I had Cerundolo making the quarter finals ðŸ™ˆ but the No. 54-ranked Canadian broke late in the first set, rallied from an early deficit in the second, and sealed the third with a key break, firing 27 winners and four aces.

Cerundolo has been a clay-court standout with a 19-9 record in 2025, but he didnâ€™t get a read on Dialloâ€™s serve and had one of those bad days at the office.

Holger Rune (10) def. Roberto Bautista Agut 6-7(4), 6-4, 6-3, 6-2

Rune battled past Bautista Agut to secure his second-round spot, setting up a date with Emilio Nava.

The Dane is on a potential fourth-round collision course with Lorenzo Musetti. With Fritz out, Rune and Musetti are the top seeds in their quarter, eyeing deep runs after Runeâ€™s back-to-back quarter-finals (2022-23) and Musettiâ€™s fourth-round showings (2021, 2023).

Jannik Sinner (1) def. Arthur Rinderknech 6-4, 6-3, 7-5

World No. 1 Jannik Sinner battled through a tricky night session on Court Philippe-Chatrier, overcoming a spirited Arthur Rinderknech and a raucous French crowd to win 6-4, 6-3, 7-5 in two hours and five minutes.

Sinner started strong, taking the first set 6-4 with 83% first-serve points won and saving all break points.

That typical Sinner precision was evident, with eight winners and just three unforced errors in the opener.

The second set saw Sinner maintain control, breaking Rinderknechâ€™s serve twice to secure a 6-3 lead, despite the Frenchmanâ€™s aggressive serve-and-volley tactics and some powerful serving.

The third set turned dramatic as Rinderknech, fueled by the home crowdâ€™s Mexican wave and cheers, surged to a 5-2 lead with two breaks of Sinnerâ€™s serve.

However, the Italian showed ice-cool composure, reeling off five straight games, capitalising on Rinderknechâ€™s 47 unforced errors and a critical double fault to seal the match.

Other Notable Results

Richard Gasquet def. Terence Atmane 6-2, 2-6, 6-3, 6-0: The Frenchman capitalised on Atmaneâ€™s cramps in the third set to roll through, and he faces Jannik Sinner next, potentially his last match at Roland Garros.

Alejandro Davidovich Fokina (26) def. Pablo Llamas Ruiz 6-3, 6-2, 6-7(4), 6-3: The Spaniard survived a third-set scare, but last season, this match would probably have gone deep into the fifth set, so kudos to Fokina.

Jacob Fearnley def. Stan Wawrinka 7-6(7), 6-3, 6-2: The Brit upset the veteran who I thought might have offered a bit more given he played nicely in some Challengers pre French Open.

Denis Shapovalov (27) def. Portero MartÃ­nez 6-2, 6-0, 6-3: Shapovalov was ruthless in a result I didnâ€™t expect, as he has been struggling for form.

Miomir Kecmanovic def. SebastiÃ¡n BÃ¡ez 6-7(3), 6-7(4), 6-4, 6-2, 6-2: A gritty five-set comeback for the Serb.

Stefanos Tsitsipas (20) def. TomÃ¡s MartÃ­n Etcheverry 7-5, 6-3, 6-4: Tsitsipas looked sharp on the clay and considering how heâ€™s been playing, seeing off Etcheverry in straights is a good showing.

Sebastian Ofner def. Jan-Lennard Struff 7-6(5), 6-3, 6-7(5), 6-2: Ofner held firm in a four-set battle, and the Austrian has played some solid stuff since he came back from his foot surgery.

Hugo Gaston def. Ugo Blanchet 2-6, 6-0, 2-6, 6-3, 6-4: Gaston fought back in a rollercoaster five-setter with his creative shot-making, reminiscent of his 2020 fourth-round run, he sets up a second-round clash with the winner of Alex de Minaur vs. Zhizhen Zhang.

Highlights

French Open 2025 Day Three Round of 128 Matches
